These are the shorter works which

a playwright and novelist. DayÂ¬
break,â€œ a marvelous gambling story,
heads the list, with Fraulein Else,â€œ

nessâ€™ stories, published in 1924,
None But the Brave,â€œ and the
Rhapsody,â€œ (1926) introducing the
Freudian theory of dreaming and

exquisitely written stories are worth
reading separately. To have them
compiled in one volume is a rare
opportunity.

00T 23 193
Arthur Schnitzler
Bold spirits say that Schnitzler, like Shaw and Ibsen,
already â€œdates.â€œ Some of his work does. Of course. But
some of it dates in a surprising fashion. Simon
Schuster published last spring Viennese Novelettes,â€œ a
volume of Schnitzler short stories, one written as early
as 1901, one as late as 1927. And the earliest is an
astonishing forerunner of that â€œstream-of-consciousnessâ€œ
manner of writing fiction which English and American
writers so noisily discovered years later. Otto SchinÂ¬
nerer's introduction to Viennese Novelettesâ€™ will suggest
sidelights to those who, reading of Schnitzlerâ€™s death,
attempt to reassess his writing. He was, we often forget,
a doctor before he became a man of letters; and a Jew
in that anti-Semitic Vienna of pre-war days in which
so many Jewish world geniuses found expressionâ€”Freud,
Felix Salten, Hugo von Hofmannsthal and Jacob WasserÂ¬
mann among them.

Viennese Noveltiesâ€œ is a volume
which has the double merit of litÂ¬
erary excellence and low cost. I am,
frankly, a Schintzler enthusiast. The
manâ€™s craftsmanship is superb.
Trained as a doctor, he dissects emoÂ¬
tions with magnificent ease and skill.
His is a precise and expert hand,
supported with understanding, symÂ¬
pathy and tolerance for human
dreams no less than human vagaries.
Some object that he is cynical. He
is unquestionably honest in his viewÂ¬
point, yet it is an honesty mellowed
by experience and tempered by a
gentle and yet compelling irony.
These Viennese Noveltiesâ€œ preÂ¬

VIENNESE NOVELETTES, by ArÂ¬
thur Schnitzler. (Simon and
Schuster.)
*
LL of the half sad, half gay
âˆ†A charm of pre-war Vienna is
simply and gracefully translated in
these five novelettes.
Master of the short story, SchnitzÂ¬
ler has created his own field by
employing in his character deÂ¬
lineation his wide knowledge of
psychological processes and feÂ¬
sponse, gleaned from his own exÂ¬
perience as a physician and from
a wide study of the findings of
others
*
The stream of consciousness
technique is employed with peneÂ¬##
â€žtration in Fraulein Else, where
exhibitionism develops with that
breakdown of inbred reticences,
and None But the Brave records
a young officerâ€™s thought processes
at a crisis in his career.
Rhapsody treats of the dual exÂ¬
istence between sleeping and wakÂ¬
ing, and Beatrice, the Oedipus
complex. Daybreak contents itself
with the presentation of a succesÂ¬
sion of characters, without comÂ¬
ment, but in the Schnitzler manÂ¬
ner of delicate fantasy surprisingÂ¬
ly blended with deep realism, that
makes comment unnecessary.
The collection is prefaced by a
sketch of the author and an outÂ¬
line of his achievements, contribÂ¬
uted by Otto P. Schinnerer.â€”
Reviewed by ZOE B. FALES.
